snippet: George W. Bush plunged into the most-populous state today for the first time as a Presidential candidate. And he immediately cast himself as more temperate than most Republican leaders here and in Washington on two ballot measures that have roiled...
lead_paragraph: George W. Bush plunged into the most-populous state today for the first time as a Presidential candidate. And he immediately cast himself as more temperate than most Republican leaders here and in Washington on two ballot measures that have roiled his party: immigration and affirmative action. Mr. Bush, the Governor of Texas, distanced himself from a proposition voters passed in California in 1994 that prohibits public services for illegal immigrants. And he refused to endorse a proposition approved by voters here in 1996 that outlawed racial preferences for hiring, education and contracts.
abstract: Gov George W Bush, campaigning for Republican Presidential nomination in California, casts self as more temperate than most Republican leaders on immigration and affirmative action; distances self from 1994 proposition that bars public services for illegal immigrants; refuses to endorse 1996 proposition that bars racial preferences for hiring, education and contracts; both measures were championed by Republican officials; Bush seems so confident of primary victory that he already seeks to broaden support in general election (M)

headline.main: California, Here Bush Comes, a Moderate on Immigration and Racial Quotas
